MaY 25, 1951
art
It wes a hopelessly corrupt and inept government which
spawned the
Chinese Communists.
The people of China yearned for sone decent Leadership, any
leadership other then whet they had.
They did not turn to Communism.
They
turned
from
the Kuoninteng.
The unplessent truth is th t the Communiats have brought
something new
to Chine.
It serves no useful purpose merely to condemn the Reds.
It is
better,
rather, to analyze their strength and look for some means of competing.
Most of those
who have lately returned from Connunist China admit that there exists
a new order of honesty.
Soldiers are well disciplined and they fight with a new
spirit.
The Communists have wrought some truly grest changes.
Traina run on time.
They do not wait for some arrogent official uno is deliberately late in order to
keep the train weiting and then strut down the platform so that all enn see the big
shot for whom the train and ell its pessengers have been inconvenienced.
Porters
refuse tips.
So
do dining car miters.
Generals and publie officials cun't be
bought.
This is no brief for Chinese or any other kind of Conuunism but if we are
to defeat them we must recognize their strength as well or even better than their
weakness and
do something about it. More of that later.
He have the opportunity
as will be shown.
The Chinese Communiats promised land reforms. The New York FORLD TELEGRAM
AND SUN of April 12th had this to say:
"Red Chine's
"land reform" has developed into a vicious
countryside wer in many areas,
with both landlords and
Red cadres sent out to divide up the fams.
In some
sections the army has had to be called out.
Chairmen Liu Shao-chi admits "agrarian reform is a
flerce struggle," but is going ahesd in East, South-
Central and Northwest China."
The above dispatch is interesting in the light of a report by Winston
Churchill in his fourth book, "The Hinge of Fate" in which he relates a conference
with Stalin as follows:
"Tell ne," I asked, "have the stresses of this war been as bad to you
personally as carrying through the polley of the Collective Farms?"
-... â€¢
"Oh, no," he said, "the Collective Fern policy was a terrible atruggle."
"I thought you would have found it bed," said I, "becuse you were not
deling with a few score thousends of aristocrats or big landowners, but with
millions of small men.*
"Ten millions," he said, holding up his hands.
"It was fearful.
Four
years it lasted.
It was absolutely necessary for fussia, if we were to avoid
periodie famines, to plough the land with tractors. He must mechanize our agri-
culture.
Then we gave tractors to the pessants they were sll spoiled in a few
mon tha.
Only Collective Farms with Workshops could handle tractors. We took
the grestest trouble to explain it to the pessents.
It was no use arguing with
then.
After you have said all you can to a persent he says he must go home and
consult his wife, and he must consult his herder.*
